joe: I may be going to London tomorrow.

option: I think Liverpool will definitely win.

question.text: If you worked less hard, you <item>may</item> feel less tired.

right: If you worked less hard, you might feel less tired.
If you worked less hard you might feel less tired.

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: I hope that the young couple <item>will</item> enjoy years of happiness.
I hope that the young couple <item>may</item> enjoy years of happiness.
I hope that the young couple <item>might</item> enjoy years of happiness.
<item>May</item> you both be very happy together!

feedback.desc: If you thought B or D was wrong, 72.1.

question.text: Which expression(s) can end the sentence: A, B or both?
question.input_text: She <item>might have told me</item> she was going to stay out all night; ...

feedback.desc:
71.8, 80.3
With meaning A, might would be stressed in speech.
With meaning B, told would be stressed.

question.text: You were stupid to try climbing up the cliff. You <item>may have killed</item> yourself.

feedback.desc:
You might have killed yourself is the traditionally correct form, but more and more people are now using may have with this meaning.
71.9

question.input_text: He <item>may be</item> clever, but he hasn’t got much common sense.
option: I agree that he’s clever, but ...
question.answer: I agree that he’s clever, but ...

exercise.rubric: Right (R) or wrong (W)?

question.text: Anna wasn’t at the station. She <item>may have missed</item> her train.
Jack isn’t answering his phone. He <item>may have gone</item> out by now.
By the end of this year I <item>may have saved</item> enough money to go to America.
One of these sentences is wrong. Which one?
option: He only left the office five minutes ago. He <item>can’t be</item> home yet.
He only left the office five minutes ago. He <item>mustn’t be</item> home yet.
She walked past without saying hello. She <item>can’t have seen</item> us.
She walked past without saying hello. She <item>mustn’t have seen</item> us.
question.answer: He only left the office five minutes ago. He mustn’t be home yet.
